text:
(1)
Hancock Street, west side, north from Houston to Bleecker
Streets, the entire length of Hancock Street.
1926.

(2)
The same, two years later, showing Hancock Street in the process of being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension. The entire west side of Hancock Street, and part of the east side, has been demolished. The municipal subway has been cut through and boarded over.
September 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Hancock Street, west side, north from Houston to Bleecker
Streets, the entire length of Hancock Street.
1926.

(2)
The same, two years later, showing Hancock Street in the process of being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension. The entire west side of Hancock Street, and part of the east side, has been demolished. The municipal subway has been cut through and boarded over.
September 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

168 West Houston Street (33 Hancock Street); and Nos. 164, 162-160, 158, north side, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Hancock Street, (the future N.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and Houston Street), seen from the northern end of Congress Street across the little plaza formed by the concurrence of Houston Street, Bedford Street, and the western section of Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street). Every single building visible in this picture is to be demolished the following year, when work begins on the new Independent (Municipal) Subway and the extension of Sixth Avenue south from its original beginning at Carmine Street and Minetta Lane. The Houston Street branch of the new subway will curve under the north side of Houston Street, where the tenement houses and moving picture theatre appear in this picture.

1926.

(1)
Bedford Street, northwest from Houston Street at Congress (Sixth Avenue Extension). Bedford Street runs northwest, parallel to the third section (originally Herring's Street) of Bleecker Street, to Christopher Street, and, like the corresponding section of Bleecker, lies almost entirely within the old Herring farm. The farm line crosses Bedford Street at Nos. 10 and 17 (about where two cars are parked together on the east side of the street a hundred feet north of the plaza).
The little plaza in the foreground is formed by the junction of the original Houston Street (from the Bowery to this point), the former Hammersley Street (at the left), which in 1858 was made part of Houston Street, and Bedford Street, which on the angle of Bleecker Street, might have been absorbed by Houston had it not been for Hammersley Street. At the right, Hancock Extension, comes into the plaza at right angles to Houston Street. At the left of View No. 2, may be seen the billboards at the right angle junction of Congress (originally Smith) Street and Houston Street.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Another view, with the cameras more to the west.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, from the ground, from and including Sixth Avenue, three and a half years later.
February 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, from the ground, from and including Sixth Avenue, three and a half years later.
February 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

West Houston Street (running from center foreground to right background), east from Hancock Street, and showing a general view of the surrounding area in a northeasterly direction. Shown under construction is the subway curve of the Independent (Eighth Ave.) System at the N.E. corner of Hancock Street. The white building, in the center, is Mills House No. 1 and is on the south side of Bleecker Street, from Sullivan to Thompson Streets.

June 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
